The time commitment for Andrew Ng's Machine Learning course on Coursera can vary depending on several factors, such as your prior knowledge of the subject, your learning pace, and the level of engagement you want to achieve. However, here's a general idea of what you can expect:

**Course duration:** The course has 11 weeks, and each week typically covers a new topic in machine learning.

**Weekly time commitment:** On average, you can expect to spend around 4-6 hours per week on coursework, which includes:

1. **Video lectures:** Each week, you'll watch around 2-3 hours of video lectures, which are divided into shorter segments (usually 10-15 minutes each).
2. **Assignments:** You'll have weekly assignments, which can take around 1-2 hours to complete. These assignments typically involve implementing machine learning algorithms in Python using the NumPy and scikit-learn libraries.
3. **Quizzes:** You'll have quizzes to test your understanding of the material, which usually take around 30 minutes to an hour to complete.
4. **Reading and reviewing:** You may also want to spend some time reading the course notes, reviewing the material, and exploring additional resources, which can add another 1-2 hours to your weekly commitment.

**Flexibility:** One of the benefits of online courses is that you can learn at your own pace. You can adjust the time you spend on coursework each week based on your schedule and learning needs.

**Tips to manage your time:**

1. **Create a schedule:** Plan out your week and set aside dedicated time for coursework.
2. **Prioritize understanding:** Focus on understanding the concepts rather than just completing the assignments quickly.
3. **Use the discussion forums:** Engage with the course community and ask questions if you're struggling with a concept.
4. **Take breaks:** Don't be afraid to take breaks and come back to the material when you're feeling refreshed.

Remember, the time commitment may vary, but with a consistent effort, you can complete the course and gain a solid understanding of machine learning concepts.
